item.title: Archaeology
item.description: Purpose Here you will find a list of resources with very archaeology-specific applications, including slides, textbooks, and packages. You will be able to find a much more comprehensive list of resources on Ben Marwick’s CRAN Task View for archaeology. üì¶ Packages install.packages() archdata rcarbon c14bazAAR evoarchdata zooaRch leastcostpath üë©‚Äçüè´ Slides Statistical inference and data exploration for archaeologists - Ben Marwick üíª Sites and Blogs Archaeoinformatics - Sophie Schmidt Plotting dental inventory with ggplot2 - Bj√∏rn Peare Bartholdy

item.title: print('Hello World')
item.description: New Website To increase our visibility, we have launched a new website (which you have obviously already found) using the Hello Friend NG Hugo theme, with some slight tweaks. Goals With this new platform, we aim to provide a convenient, centralised location for all your Rchaeological needs, from general R resources for beginners, to more advanced R topics in archaeology and related disciplines. We will offer occasional posts on various topics on a completely unpredictable schedule.

item.title: Beginners
item.description: üëã Welcome So you want to learn R? Here are some resources that will help you on your jouRney to awesomeness! üíª Installing R and RStudio Danielle Navarro slides and youtube video ‚å®Ô∏è Console swirl R package # enter the following in the R console install.packages("swirl") library("swirl") üè´ Online Courses and Tutorials Getting Started with R - free course by R for the Rest of Us Data carpentry R for Social Scientists R for Ecologists R for beginners by Ihnwhi Heo, Duco Veen, and Rens van de Schoot

item.title: About
item.description: Rchaeology Rchaeology is a community for archaeologists who use, and want to learn R statistical software. Goals We aspire to make the R programming language accessible to all archaeologists, and provide an open, welcoming community for all those who are interested in learning. We also want to help Rchaeologists find one another, whether for collaboration, getting help with field-specific R questions, or just to nerd out and chat about R.
